channel.title: Dual Nvidia 460's or 1 480?
channel.description: well im considering buying a new graphics setup, and im stuck between dual EVGA nvidia 460's or a single 480 :S what's your thoughts on this?

item.title: Dual Nvidia 460's or 1 480?
item.dc:creator: @shrogg shrogg
item.description:
@shrogg wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:15, topic:376665”][quote author=shrogg link=topic=472589.msg3457172#msg3457172 date=1294118574]
custom water cooling setup (im using a old 50CC motorbike radiator as the radiator :D)
[/quote]
hahahaha I can’t wait to see this explode all over your new cards and fry them.

on the bright side you won’t have to clean it up since the cards will boil most of it off on contact![/quote]

Lol, well i am using propper Watercooling parts, like the tubing and actual copper plates that attatch to the GPU, the pump will be a legit one for the mineral oil that i will be using and the radiator (which normally costs between $30-$80) will be free (from my cuz)

and btw, i also thought about a total submersion in mineral oil, but what a mess if you want to change something around or take it somewhere…
so i will do that to my XBOX 360

Read full topic

item.title: Dual Nvidia 460's or 1 480?
item.dc:creator: @shrogg shrogg
item.description:
@shrogg wrote:

well i just thought that you can set these cards up in tripple sli and even quad (i think) and atm at my income getting another 480 will take around 1.2 years :S
so i think im going for the 2 460s.
ill probably OC them with my soon-to-be custom water cooling setup (im using a old 50CC motorbike radiator as the radiator :D) wich is only costing me $60
so yeah, i will OC the fuck out of the 2 460s and watercool them

item.title: Dual Nvidia 460's or 1 480?
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

The GTX 460 slightly outperforms the 280, and two of them together are better than two 280s, because NVIDIA have really worked on the scaling for the 400 series cards.

Read full topic

item.title: Dual Nvidia 460's or 1 480?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I don’t know if it is that way now, but back when I last bought cards, for example, a 7800GTX was a much faster/better card then an 8600. So I assumed the 280GTX would be faster than the 460. Maybe lacking DX11 support, but is it faster?

Read full topic

item.title: Dual Nvidia 460's or 1 480?
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

List of games with DirectX 11 support

This is a list of released and upcoming games that support DirectX 11 (available for Windows Vista and later) or DirectX 11.1 (available for Windows 8 and later and partially available for Windows 7 via the Platform Update). Information regarding developer, publisher, date of release and genre is provided where available.

Besides. What would be the point in buying old cards? It isn’t as if the 460s are all that more expensive, if at all, why not be able to run say, Crysis 2 when it comes out in all its glory, in DirectX 11 with your two cards that you bought so you could run everything as best as possible?

It doesn’t make sense to not buy a new card without DirectX 11, that you are buying for gaming - because not only is the range of cards that support it quite big, you don’t have to pay a premium for it.

Read full topic

item.title: Dual Nvidia 460's or 1 480?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Thug-life, post:9, topic:376665”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=472589.msg3456901#msg3456901 date=1294101219]
Honestly you always get the best bang for your buck going with 2 of the top-of-the-line previous generation cards.

So I’d recommend 2 280GTXs (or whatever the top-of-the-line 280 was, it’s been far too long since I bought a card…).
[/quote]
Yeah, but they don’t support DX11. If you’re buying two such cards now, then you’ll want that power to be able to handle the absolute best - and some of that will be in DX11.[/quote]

There is always a new thing, but chances are you are never going to use it. What games currently support DX11? (And with a new technology, the first adopters never look as good as it could, sometimes not even as good as the previous implementation.) You wouldn’t be able to tell the difference anyway.

I guarantee that no game is going to require DX11 before even the 480GTX is so out dated that it couldn’t play it anyway.

Read full topic

item.title: Dual Nvidia 460's or 1 480?

item.description:
@tL wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:7, topic:376665”]Honestly you always get the best bang for your buck going with 2 of the top-of-the-line previous generation cards.

So I’d recommend 2 280GTXs (or whatever the top-of-the-line 280 was, it’s been far too long since I bought a card…).[/quote]
Yeah, but they don’t support DX11. If you’re buying two such cards now, then you’ll want that power to be able to handle the absolute best - and some of that will be in DX11.

Read full topic

item.title: Dual Nvidia 460's or 1 480?
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

One 480. SLI and crossfire isn’t perfect, and having one single, powerful GPU will always be more reliable in their use in games.

Two in SLI may give you 10 or so more FPS in games, but the 480 will always give you enough performance and you always have the option for then going for another 480 when they drop in price, if you have a sufficient PSU, that is.

Read full topic

item.title: Dual Nvidia 460's or 1 480?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Keep in mind the extra power requirements of 2 cards will mean a single more expensive card will cost less in the long run(say over a year or longer, regular use) and you’ll probably have less issues with space and heat.

Read full topic
